body:
I noticed the rook-operator pod had 1 restart:
```
> kubectl get pod
NAME                              READY     STATUS    RESTARTS   AGE
rook-operator-2761695524-th25c    1/1       Running   1          10m
wordpress-255188236-ns24k         1/1       Running   0          2m
wordpress-mysql-830254888-jldzd   1/1       Running   0          2m
```

Looking at the previous pod instance logs, we see a panic:
```
> kubectl logs --previous=true rook-operator-2761695524-th25c
2017-02-27 23:52:58.931447 I | rook-operator: starting operator in namespace default
2017-02-27 23:52:58.931645 I | operator: creating rook TPR
2017-02-27 23:53:07.969332 I | operator: start watching rook tpr: 0
2017-02-27 23:53:07.971781 I | operator: start watching at 0
2017-02-27 23:53:07.973595 I | operator: starting cluster. &{Namespace:rook factory:0xc4f74e0 clientset:0xc4200489a0 Metadata:{Name: GenerateName: Namespace: SelfLink: UID: ResourceVersion: Generation:0 CreationTimestamp:0001-01-01 00:00:00 +0000 UTC DeletionTimestamp:<nil> DeletionGracePeriodSeconds:<nil> Labels:map[] Annotations:map[] OwnerReferences:[] Finalizers:[] ClusterName:} Spec:{Namespace: Version:dev-2017-02-27-k8s Paused:false UseAllDevices:false}}
2017-02-27 23:53:07.981285 I | op-mon: start running mons
2017-02-27 23:53:07.984505 I | op-mon: creating mon secrets for a new cluster
2017-02-27 23:53:08.025627 I | op-mon: saved rook-admin secret
2017-02-27 23:53:08.030518 I | op-mon: there are 2 nodes available for 3 monitors
2017-02-27 23:53:08.035853 I | op-mon: 0 running, 0 pending pods
2017-02-27 23:53:08.050634 I | op-mon: waiting 6s for pod mon0 to start. status=
2017-02-27 23:53:14.056081 I | op-mon: waiting 6s for pod mon0 to start. status=
2017-02-27 23:53:20.061363 I | op-mon: waiting 6s for pod mon0 to start. status=
2017-02-27 23:53:26.066015 I | op-mon: waiting 6s for pod mon0 to start. status=
2017-02-27 23:53:32.073562 I | op-mon: pod mon0 started
2017-02-27 23:53:32.090926 I | op-mon: waiting 6s for pod mon1 to start. status=
2017-02-27 23:53:38.097995 I | op-mon: waiting 6s for pod mon1 to start. status=
2017-02-27 23:53:44.105030 I | op-mon: waiting 6s for pod mon1 to start. status=
2017-02-27 23:53:50.110483 I | op-mon: waiting 6s for pod mon1 to start. status=
2017-02-27 23:53:56.115595 I | op-mon: pod mon1 started
2017-02-27 23:53:56.130365 I | op-mon: waiting 6s for pod mon2 to start. status=
2017-02-27 23:54:02.138551 I | op-mon: pod mon2 started
2017-02-27 23:54:02.138649 I | op-mon: started 3/3 mons (0 already running)
2017-02-27 23:54:02.138698 I | op-api: starting the Rook api
2017-02-27 23:54:02.154622 I | op-api: API service running at 10.3.0.115:8124
2017-02-27 23:54:02.177650 I | op-api: api deployment started
2017-02-27 23:54:02.177704 I | op-osd: start running osds
2017-02-27 23:54:02.225130 I | op-osd: osd daemon set started
2017-02-27 23:54:02.225346 I | cephmon: connecting to ceph cluster rookcluster with user admin
panic: unexpected long blocking (> 1 Minute) when handling cluster event

goroutine 97 [running]:
panic(0x2da8dc0, 0xc4201b5e80)
	/usr/local/go/src/runtime/panic.go:500 +0x1a1
github.com/rook/rook/pkg/operator/k8sutil.(*PanicTimer).Start.func1()
	/home/rook/go/src/github.com/rook/rook/pkg/operator/k8sutil/timer.go:39 +0x5d
created by time.goFunc
	/usr/local/go/src/time/sleep.go:154 +0x44
```

It seems like if the cluster creation takes longer than 1 minute, we would hit this.  Perhaps the 1 minute panic is too aggressive for the handling of a cluster "Added" event?

milestone.description: In this milestone we will focus on reliability of running rook on bare metal and getting a baseline for performance. We also are going to pursue a pluggable orchestration backend that enables us to integrate more deeply with Kubernetes, and possibly others in the future.
milestone.title: v0.3

title: rook-operator: panic: unexpected long blocking (> 1 Minute) when handling cluster event
